question: A spring-mass system oscillates with a period of 0.5 seconds. If the mass is doubled while the spring constant remains unchanged, what will be the new period of oscillation?
solution: The period of a spring-mass system is given by T = 2π√(m/k), where m is the mass and k is the spring constant. If the mass is doubled (m → 2m) while the spring constant remains the same, the new period will be T_new = 2π√(2m/k) = 2π√(2)√(m/k) = √2 * T_original. Since the original period was 0.5 s, the new period will be T_new = √2 * 0.5 s ≈ 0.71 s.
